events.originalText: A siege of a hotel in Mogadishu by al-Shabaab militants, which began the previous day and killed at least 20 people, ended with the Somali Armed Forces recapturing the premises.
events.subtitle: Makka al-Mukarama hotel attack
events.headline: Siege of Mogadishu hotel by al-Shabaab militants ends with Somali Armed Forces recapturing premises

events.originalText: Invasion of Iraq: In a friendly fire incident, two members of the United States Air Force attacked the United Kingdom's Blues and Royals regiment, killing one soldier and injuring five.
events.subtitle: 2003 invasion of Iraq
events.headline: Friendly fire incident in Iraq: US Air Force attacks UK regiment, killing one soldier

events.originalText: Serbian police and special forces killed about 93 Kosovo Albanians in the village of Izbica in the Drenica region of central Kosovo.
events.subtitle: Izbica massacre
events.headline: Serbian police and special forces kill 93 Kosovo Albanians in village of Izbica

events.originalText: In the Tragedy of Otranto, the Italian Navy vessel Sibilla collided with the Albanian civilian vessel Kateri i Radës, causing the latter to sink and leading to dozens of deaths.
events.subtitle: Tragedy of Otranto
events.headline: Tragedy of Otranto: Italian Navy vessel collides with Albanian civilian vessel, leading to dozens of deaths

events.originalText: British prime minister James Callaghan was defeated by one vote in a vote of no confidence after his government struggled to cope with widespread strikes during the Winter of Discontent.
events.subtitle: James Callaghan
events.headline: British PM James Callaghan defeated by one vote in vote of no confidence

events.originalText: The US Department of State released the Acheson–Lilienthal Report, a proposal for international control of nuclear weapons.
events.subtitle: United States Department of State
events.headline: US Department of State releases Acheson–Lilienthal Report on nuclear weapons control

events.originalText: Second World War: The port of Saint-Nazaire in occupied France was disabled by British naval forces.
events.subtitle: World War II
events.headline: British naval forces disable port of Saint-Nazaire in occupied France during Second World War

events.originalText: After an on-board fire that may have been the first incident of airliner sabotage, the Imperial Airways biplane City of Liverpool broke apart in mid-air, killing fifteen people.
events.subtitle: Imperial Airways
events.headline: Imperial Airways biplane breaks apart in mid-air after suspected sabotage, killing fifteen

events.originalText: World War I: British and Australian troops defeated German forces at the First Battle of Dernancourt in northern France.
events.subtitle: World War I
events.headline: British and Australian troops defeat German forces at First Battle of Dernancourt in World War I

events.originalText: The Vienna Philharmonic (pictured) held its first concert, conducted by Otto Nicolai.
events.subtitle: Vienna Philharmonic
events.headline: Vienna Philharmonic holds first concert conducted by Otto Nicolai

events.originalText: German astronomer Heinrich Wilhelm Matthias Olbers discovered Pallas, the second asteroid ever identified, although it was considered to be a planet at the time.
events.subtitle: Heinrich Wilhelm Matthias Olbers
events.headline: German astronomer discovers second asteroid, Pallas, considered a planet at the time

events.originalText: The Praetorian Guard assassinated Roman emperor Pertinax and sold the imperial office in an auction to Didius Julianus (coin pictured).
events.subtitle: Praetorian Guard
events.headline: Praetorian Guard assassinates Roman emperor Pertinax, sells imperial office in auction to Didius Julianus
